newsitem.title: USA: USDA sees wheat prices $3.25-$3.35 July-Sept.
newsitem.headline: USDA sees wheat prices $3.25-$3.35 July-Sept.

text.p: U.S. wheat prices will probably "bottom out" sometime between July and September between $3.25 to $3.35 per bushel, Agriculture Department chief economist Keith Collins said.

In a speech at USDA's annual Agricultural Outlook Forum, Collins said since 1980, in years of significant stock growth of 20 percent or more, wheat prices start higher and decline more early in the crop year, reaching a trough in late summer before generally rising through May.
Wheat ending stocks are seen climbing to 550 million bushels in 1997/98 from 474 million bushels in 1996/97.

Collins said this year's corn prices may be relatively firmer than wheat. Though corn carryover stocks are expected to be relatively tight, and feed and industrial uses are rising, exports will be down due to increased competition.
